mdRecord.dcterms:title: Congress Hall Hotel, general view
mdRecord.dcterms:creator: Meyer, J. F. (American architect, active 19th century) [work]
Wilson, Richard Guy [photographer]
mdRecord.dcterms:publisher: Rector and Visitors of the University of Virginia
mdRecord.dcterms:description: Congress Hall was constructed in 1816 as a boarding house for guests at the new seaside resort of Cape May; and the proprietor, Thomas H. Hughes, called it "The Big House." Locals, thinking it too big to be successful, called it "Tommy's Folly."[1] In 1828, when Hughes was elected to the House of Representatives, he changed the name of his hotel to Congress Hall. Congress Hall burned to the ground in Cape May's Great Fire of 1878, but within a year, its owners had rebuilt the hotel in brick. -- http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Congress_Hall_(Cape_May_hotel) [work]
